name: Banyan Tree
description: The national tree of India, known for its aerial prop roots that grow downward and form new trunks. Can spread over several acres and live for centuries. Sacred in Hindu, Jain, and Buddhist traditions.
uses: Shade tree; Traditional medicine; Religious and cultural significance; Avenue tree
wildlife: Fruits eaten by birds, bats, and monkeys

name: Neem Tree
description: Known as the 'village pharmacy' for its extensive medicinal properties. Highly valued in Ayurveda and used for pest control. Drought-resistant and thrives in harsh conditions.
uses: Medicinal uses; Natural pesticide; Timber; Traditional toothbrush (datun); Cosmetics
wildlife: Provides nectar for bees
nativeRange: Indian subcontinent, now widespread in tropics

name: Peepal Tree
description: Sacred tree in Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism. Known as the Bodhi tree under which Buddha attained enlightenment. Heart-shaped leaves rustle in the slightest breeze.
uses: Religious significance; Shade tree; Traditional medicine; Oxygen production 24/7
wildlife: Fruits eaten by birds and bats

name: Mango Tree
description: The national fruit tree, cultivated for over 4,000 years. Produces delicious fruits and is deeply embedded in Indian culture. Over 1,000 varieties exist in India.
uses: Edible fruit; Timber; Leaves used in rituals; Mango wood for furniture; Pickles and chutneys
wildlife: Fruits eaten by birds, bats, and mammals

name: Indian Rosewood
description: Also called Shisham, highly valued for its durable, beautiful wood. Used extensively in fine furniture and musical instruments. Wood has distinctive fragrance.
uses: Premium furniture; Musical instruments (especially tablas); Veneer; Agricultural implements
wildlife: Flowers attract bees

name: Teak
description: World-renowned timber tree with golden-brown wood. Extremely durable and weather-resistant. Major plantation species for commercial forestry.
uses: High-quality timber for furniture; Shipbuilding; Veneer and plywood; Outdoor furniture
wildlife: Flowers attract bees and butterflies
nativeRange: Central India, naturalized in South India
fallColor: Deciduous, large leaves drop in winter

name: Sal Tree
description: Sacred tree in Hinduism and Buddhism. Dominant tree in Sal forests of northern and central India. Important timber species.
uses: Durable timber for construction; Resin for incense and medicine; Leaves used as plates; Firewood
wildlife: Seeds eaten by wildlife

name: Jamun Tree
description: Also called Black Plum or Java Plum. Produces purple-black fruits with medicinal properties, especially for diabetes. Fruits stain tongue purple.
uses: Edible fruit; Medicinal uses for diabetes; Vinegar production; Wood for furniture; Natural dye
wildlife: Fruits eaten by birds and bats

name: Indian Almond
description: Coastal tree with large leaves that turn red before falling. Nuts edible but hard to crack. Provides excellent shade.
uses: Shade tree; Edible nuts; Tannin from bark; Traditional medicine; Leaves used in aquariums
wildlife: Fruits eaten by bats and birds

name: Coconut Palm
description: Known as 'Kalpavriksha' (tree of life). Every part used - fruit, water, oil, leaves, trunk. Integral to coastal Indian culture and economy.
uses: Edible fruit and water; Copra for oil; Leaves for thatching; Coir from husk; Timber; Toddy drink
wildlife: Fruits eaten by wildlife when opened

name: Arjun Tree
description: Sacred tree with significant medicinal value, especially for heart ailments. Bark widely used in Ayurvedic medicine. Large spreading crown.
uses: Ayurvedic heart medicine; Timber for construction; Tannin from bark; Avenue tree; Sericulture (host for tussar silkworm)
wildlife: Flowers attract bees

name: Indian Sandalwood
description: Highly valued for fragrant heartwood used in perfumes, cosmetics, and religious ceremonies. Slow-growing and highly protected. Oil worth more than gold by weight.
uses: Perfume and essential oil; Incense; Religious and ceremonial use; Wood carving; Traditional medicine
wildlife: Limited wildlife value

name: Indian Laburnum
description: Golden Shower Tree, covered in hanging clusters of bright yellow flowers. State flower of Kerala. Used in Ayurvedic medicine.
uses: Ornamental flowering tree; Ayurvedic medicine (laxative); Timber; Pulp from pods used traditionally
wildlife: Flowers attract bees and butterflies

name: Ashoka Tree
description: Sacred to Hindus, associated with love and fertility. Fragrant orange-red flowers. Name means 'without sorrow' in Sanskrit.
uses: Ornamental tree in temple gardens; Ayurvedic medicine for women's health; Bark used medicinally; Religious ceremonies
wildlife: Flowers attract insects

name: Gulmohar
description: Flame Tree or Royal Poinciana. Spectacular display of bright red-orange flowers in summer. One of the most colorful trees in the tropics.
uses: Ornamental shade tree; Avenue tree; Pods used in traditional medicine; Timber occasionally
wildlife: Flowers attract birds, especially parrots
nativeRange: Native to Madagascar, naturalized in India

name: Indian Cork Tree
description: Tree Jasmine, produces fragrant white flowers at night. Long tubular flowers resembling jasmine. Popular ornamental.
uses: Ornamental flowering tree; Perfume industry; Avenue tree; Flowers used in garlands
wildlife: Night-blooming flowers attract moths and bats

name: Kadam Tree
description: Fast-growing with spherical orange flowers. Sacred in Hinduism, associated with Lord Krishna. Smooth gray bark.
uses: Timber for plywood and pulp; Ornamental tree; Traditional medicine; Flowers used in worship
wildlife: Flowers attract bees, fruits eaten by birds

name: Mahua Tree
description: Flowers and fruits important for tribal communities. Flowers dried and eaten or fermented for liquor. Seeds yield oil.
uses: Edible flowers; Mahua liquor; Seed oil for cooking and soap; Timber; Tribal cuisine
wildlife: Flowers attract elephants, bears, and deer

name: Indian Elm
description: Fast-growing hardy tree for dry regions. Used for erosion control and agroforestry. Tolerates harsh conditions.
soil: Well-drained, tolerates poor and dry soil
uses: Timber for agricultural implements; Fuelwood; Erosion control; Fodder for cattle
wildlife: Limited wildlife value

name: Jackfruit Tree
description: Produces the largest tree-borne fruit in the world, up to 80 pounds. Fruit has numerous culinary uses. Fast-growing and productive.
uses: Edible fruit (raw and cooked); Timber for furniture and musical instruments; Leaves as fodder; Young fruit as vegetable
wildlife: Fruits eaten by elephants and other large mammals
nativeRange: Western Ghats, now cultivated throughout India
